Although it is labelled 'point patterns in absolute space', the real (ahem) _point_ of this figure is that spatial analysis often works, in effect, with a relative concept of space, since it is based on notions as here, such as the distances between points.

If you want point patterns, you need [the fantastic `spatstat`](https://github.com/spatstat) by Adrian Baddeley, Ege Rubak, and Rolf Turner.


::: {.cell hash='fig2-04-ppa-relative-space_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-1_d9665f150ebc01b59e617d6630096509'}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(spatstat)
```
:::


Make a couple of point patterns, one evenly-space using _sequential spatial inhibition_, and one clustered using a _Thomas process_. For the latter, see

> Thomas M. 1949. A generalisation of Poisson's binomial limit for use in ecology. _Biometrika_ **36**, 18â€“25.


::: {.cell hash='fig2-04-ppa-relative-space_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_76500446864586cb031d5b516acd1617'}

```{.r .cell-code}
pp1 <- rSSI(0.07, n = 105)
pp2 <- rThomas(10, 0.03, 10)
```
:::


Calculate nearest neighbour distances.


::: {.cell hash='fig2-04-ppa-relative-space_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_163d16d785f4f338bee8eb06fd8d7227'}

```{.r .cell-code}
nn1 <- nndist(pp1)
nn2 <- nndist(pp2)
breaks <- seq(0, round(max(c(nn1, nn2)), 1), length.out = 10)
```
:::


And plot them.


::: {.cell hash='fig2-04-ppa-relative-space_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-4_93ac3f84c50cbf183a8de4e4f2d3af96'}

```{.r .cell-code}
par(mfrow = c(2, 2), mai = rep(0.3, 4))

plot(pp1, main = "")
hist(nn1, main = "", xlab = "Distance", ylab = "Frequency", breaks = breaks)
plot(pp2, main = "")
hist(nn2, main = "", xlab = "Distance", ylab = "Frequency", breaks = breaks)
```
